awd_titl_txt: CRII: CIF: Learning Hidden Structures in Networks: Fundamental Limits and Efficient Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
The problem of learning hidden structures in network data arises in many contemporary applications such as recommender systems, network privacy, and genomics. This problem intersects high-dimensional statistical inference and large-scale network analysis. On the one hand, classical statistical paradigm focuses on optimal statistical performance of learning algorithms, while it neglects computational complexity that becomes increasingly critical as network data gets big. On the other hand, computer scientists mostly focus on computationally efficient approximation algorithms for worst-case instances, while they neglect the underlying statistical structures that can be potentially exploited to improve the algorithm performance. This research combines both statistical and computational perspectives to characterize fundamental performance limits and develop efficient optimal algorithms for learning hidden structures in networks. 

This research has two interrelated thrusts: graphon estimation and graph matching. Graphon estimation learns the underlying generating mechanism of a network from a single snapshot of the network. Graph matching matches the vertex sets of two graphs with correlated edges to minimize the number of adjacency disagreements. This research involves: (1) developing efficient algorithms for graphon estimation and graph matching by exploiting insights from spectral graph theory, convex relaxations, and statistical physics; (2) deriving sharp statistical performance limits by drawing tools from information theory, convex duality theory, and random matrix theory; (3) identifying fundamental computational barriers which limit computationally efficient procedures from attaining the optimal statistical performance. The investigator also deploys the algorithms developed in this research to real network data, leading to fast and accurate algorithms for preference elicitation in recommender systems, de-anonymization in social networks, and DNA assembly in genomics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has substantially progressed our understanding of learning hidden structures in networks. In particular, the PI has developed efficient algorithms for graphon estimation and characterized its performance limits. This result significantly improved the state-of-the-art performance guarantees and identified a computational gap between the statistical limit and the performance limit of computationally efficient algorithms. Furthermore, the PI has initiated a statistical analysis of matching two random graphs with correlated edges. The sharp information-theoretic thresholds are characterized and efficient algorithms are devised to succeed close to the thresholds.  The algorithms have been successfully deployed to match deformable 3-D shapes in computer vision and friendship networks across different universities. Finally, the PI has studied the problem of recovering various hidden subgraphs that lack low-rank structures, including Hamiltonian cycles, k-nearest neighbor graphs, and bipartite matchings. Both sharp information-theoretic thresholds and optimal algorithms are developed. Notably, the linear programming algorithm for hidden Hamiltonian cycle recovery has been successfully deployed to the real DNA sequence data, showing significant performance improvements over existing approaches. 

 

The PI has furthered the educational goals of the present research project through mentoring both undergraduate and graduate students. He led a team of undergraduate students to work on a Data+ project, which is a full-time ten-week undergraduate summer research program organized by the Information Initiative at Duke. He also advised an undergraduate student under the summer research internship. The research findings in this project into have been incorporated into a new Ph.D. class on Statistical Inference in Graphs. The extensive lecture notes are publicly available online and have reportedly been used for teaching at other institutions. The PI also has organized many seminars and workshops, including the invited sessions at conferences such as the INFORMS meetings and the Allerton conference, the CMO-Banff International Workshop, and  the Workshop on Operations Research and Data Science. The developed algorithms have been made available on the PI’s website and Github. The PI has co-written a survey article on information-theoretic and computational limits of planted models, and also contributed a survey article on convex relaxations for community detection.
